text: Patient: Yeah. I - Doctor: Well, I mean, I don’t know. I can find out from the group at Cornell which sounds like at least would be- Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Within striking distance for you from, from the east coast. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: How quickly? If you’re eligible, how quickly you could uh- Patient: Sure. Sure. Doctor: You could go on before you uh, I think their trial is a, so it’s called a phase one trial. So what does that mean? So phase one traditionally was uh a dose-finding trial. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So it determines how toxic things were. Patient: Um hum. Um hum. Doctor: So with drugs what will often happen is a patient on a phase one where you came at an early stage you’d get a very low dose, probably too low to have toxicity but too low to be effective. And when you get to the high dose, it might be plenty to be effective but toxic, so you’d always sort of be Goldilocks at the end. Patient: Yeah.

text: Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: I would say I wouldn’t want to look back and not do everything I could have done. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: We might not cure you, but I think psychologically, you know I’ve done everything I can. Family Member: Uh hum. Doctor: But that you know, people feel differently. The only thing I say is you know to people is you really, really do have to do the radiation and the hormones. Family Member: Um hum. Patient: Yeah, yeah. Doctor: And that’s, and the data is clear. Everything else we’re doing you have to do is you know unmeasurable. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: Because if you do the radiation and hormones you have a fifty/fifty shot at being cured. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: So if the cancer never comes back you don’t know if what we did helped or not. Right, I admit that.

text: Patient: Yeah. (Pause) Doctor: Well, you folks let’s do this, okay? I -- I’m gonna put the prescription into the pharmacy here, and they’re gonna start checking as to how much it’s gonna cost you. You may say that we don’t have a prescription plan or it’s too expensive, and I can’t do it for that reason. It may be that we get through that and the door’s still open for the study because you can afford it and we can get started. Okay? But you guys have to talk about it as a family. You’ve got the paperwork to read. You can go through it, discuss it. You know, okay, this would mean that we’re gonna have to commit to going down to Baltimore every other week this time, do some more bloodwork. These are the things that I worry about. Yeah, we’re all good for that. Okay? Because you’re not on the study until you meet again with us, that your PSA is rising on the enzalutamide Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay? So we have to get the enzalutamide started (Pause) Patient: Okay. Okay. Lemme just, so the enzalutamide, the Xtandi, okay. Doctor: That’s all we’re going to start now, and you have to get worse on it to be able to be eligible for the study. (Pause15sec) Patient: Well. We would start first with the Xtandi. I have to – the disease has to progress some more – Doctor: Uh, by PSA only. Patient: Oh, okay. Doctor: I don’t think you’re gonna need new scans, but that maybe sort of something down the road, but I think you, you really just have to have a rising PSA on the enzalutamide, and then we have to repeat that ARV seven. It has to be positive on enzalutamide, and then you can go onto the study. (Pause) Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Okay. So, we can follow up that you can afford it. If you want it, then you have to decide, “Okay, I’m gonna take it.” With the idea that you’re going towards this, and maybe about a thirteen percent chance that the PSA will drop just because we added back the Xtandi. Okay?

text: Patient: I don’t know. Doctor: I don’t know either. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: They just said it was inadequate. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: So we don’t have any results about are there gene studies that you could go on. Uhm, so the ARV7 positive means that you know your cancer is pretty smart and knows how to grow despite testosterone being low, despite being on drugs like the Zytiga or the Xtandi, and that really you know as I said last time, at some point we have to decide when your cancer is worse. I tend not to rely on PSA. Patient: Mm. Doctor: It really is are there new things about you that are going in the wrong direction and yet after radiation, it seems like things are in a better direction at least in the last month in terms of your pain. Patient: Oh yes, absolutely. Doctor: We’ve got a CAT scan that I don’t have access to, but sort of what does that show? And with you know new belly films you know to sort of say what’s going on in your liver, you know so Dr. G___ and I can talk about that, sort of when, what images we need, to say okay his PSA is higher and on scan we see more cancer. And you know some of what we’re really talking about is what do we do if we tell you that. Does that bring up questions? Patient: In other words where do we go from here? Doctor: What is your understanding or what Dr. G__ talked about. Patient: Nothing really new that I remember that he thought you know with the ARB7, is that it?

text: Patient: Right. Doctor: So, for us to think about this trial as an option for you, we would have to restart the Xtandi – Patient: Uh, huh. Doctor: Check your PSA in a couple weeks and knowing that your ARV seven positive, it’s very likely that the PSA will still be higher. (Pause) Patient: Okay. Doctor: It’s different. It’s new. There is buzz out there, but the bottom line in prostate cancer is we don’t know how well these drugs work, if at all. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So, it has less side effects than chemotherapy but has more risks than chemotherapy because if we do turn on your immune system really good, attack you, you could be bad. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Okay? Family Member: That’s if it ends up going bad versus -- uh, activated immune system. Doctor: We often use steroids, and we try to sort of dampen it – Family Member: Okay.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
